refentry:
trans1trans-allDRA TDF to assembly translatorstrans386 options-Dswitch-a-h-kswitchinput-fileoutput-filealphatransoptions-Dswitch-Sinput-filebinary-assembler-filesymbol-table-filesymbolic-assembler-filehppatrans options-Dswitch-hinput-fileoutput-filemipstrans options-Dswitch-Sinput-fileop.Gop.Hop.spowertransoptionsinput-fileoutput-filesparctransoptions-Dswitchinput-fileoutput-file-Aswitch-Cswitch-Fswitch-Iswitch-Kstr-Mswitch-Rswitch-Uswitch-X-Bswitch-E-H-P-Q-V-Wswitch-ZDescription
The code production portion of the TDF compiler is under the control of a TDF translator, which translates a TDF capsule into assembly.
alphatrans produces an AXP assembler file.
There are separate TDF translators for each target architecture.
hppatrans produces assembly code for the HP PA-RISC machines.
mipstrans produces MIPS code. There are two versions, one for IRIX, and one for ULTRIX. Both produce .G and .H files required by as1, but may also optionally give .s assembly files using -S. Note that full run-time diagnostic information cannot be transmitted through the MIPS assembler, as(1).
powertrans produces assembly code common to the rs6000 and the POWERPc.
sparctrans produces SPARC assembly code. There are two versions, one for SunOS, and one for Solaris.
The various different translators are referred to collectively as trans.
It is recommended that trans should not be invoked directly, but via the user interface tcc1. The file -opt can be passed to trans by passing the option -Wt,-opt to tcc1.Options
The options denoted by a capital letter are common to the TDF installers for all the architectures, although the defaults vary for each translator.
Lowercase options are specific to each translator.
The option -a is specific to trans386.
The options -h and -d are specific to hppatrans.
switch stands for either 0, to switch an option off, or 1, to switch it on.
The default states for common options differ per translator:Per-translator defaults for common options
Optiontrans386alphatranshppatransmipstranspowertranssparctrans
-Aswitch✓✓✓✓✓✓
-Fswitch✓✗✓✓✓✓
-Iswitch✓✓✓✓✓✓
-Kstr✓(no effect)(no effect)(no effect)✗(no effect)
-Mswitch✓✓✓✓✓✓
-Rswitch✗✗✓✗✓✗
-X✗✗✗✗✗✗
-Bswitch✓✓✓✓✓✓
-Cswitch✓✓✓✓✓✓
-Dswitch✗
This option is not supported on SCO or DragonFly, and on Linux is supported only for ELF.✗✗
See also -d.✓
This option is not supported on ULTRIX.–✗
-E✗✗✗✗✗✗
-H✗✗
See also -h.✗✗✗✗
-P✗
Not supported on Solaris.✗
Not fully implemented.✗✗✗✗
-Q✗✗✗✗✗✗
-S–✗–✗––
-Uswitch✓✓✓✓✓✓
-V✗✗✗✗✗✗
-Wswitch(no effect)(no effect)(no effect)(no effect)(no effect)(no effect)
-Z✗✗✗✗✗✗
TODO: now go through and find undocumented options...
Optimisation-specific common options
The common options pertaining to optimisation are:-Aswitch
This option determines whether trans should inline calls to alloca.
For all translators, this is done by default.-Cswitch
This option determines whether trans should apply the "constants out of loops" optimisation.
For all translators, this is done by default.-Fswitch
For trans386, this option determines whether the "strength reduction" optimisation should be applied.
For alphatrans, this option determines whether or not the "for all" optimisation should be applied.
For hppatrans, mipstrans and sparctrans, this option determines whether the "for all" optimisation should be applied.
For all translators except alphatrans, this is done by default.-Iswitch
This option determines whether trans should apply the "inlining" optimisation.
For all translators, this is done by default.-Kstr
Causes trans to optimise its code for a particular processor model, determined by str.
For trans386, the available values of str are:
OptionProcessor
-K380386
-K4 (default)80486
-K5Pentium
For powertrans, the available values of str are:
OptionProcessor
-KPPOWERPc
-KRrs6000
For all other translators, at present there are no valid values for str.-Mswitch
If this option is on, trans preserves division by a floating point number rather than replacing it by multiplication by the reciprocal of the number. While the latter produces faster code, it may lead to rounding errors.
For all translators, by default, division by constants is preserved.-Rswitch
This option determines whether trans should immediately round every floating point operation to its appropriate range. This produces slower code, but is necessary for strict IEEE conformance.
The default is not to round after every operation for all translators except hppatrans and powertrans.-Uswitch
This option determines whether trans should apply the "loop unrolling" optimisation.
For all translators, this is done by default.-X
This option disables all optimisations. All trans' optimisations are believed to be valid, so that any error in optimisation is a genuine bug.
Various optimisations are performed by default for all translators.Other common options
Common options not related to optimisation are:-Bswitch
This option determines whether trans should report floating point constants which exceed their range.
For all translators, this is done by default.
If this option is switched off such constants are replaced by infinity.-Dswitch
This option determines whether trans should produce Position Independent Code (PIC).
For all translators where it is supported, except mipstrans, this is not done by default.
For trans386, this option is not supported on the SCO or DragonFly platforms, and on the Linux platform it is supported only for ELF binary format.
For hppatrans, the translator-specific option -dswitch is also provided. The -D flag emulates cc's +Z flag, -d emulates cc's +z flag. Neither option has yet been tested.
For mipstrans, this is done by default in the IRIX version and not at all in the ULTRIX version.-E
This option disables trans' constant overflow checks.
For all translators, this is done by default.-H
This option causes trans to output debugging information in its output file. This will only work if the input TDF capsule contains debugging information.
For trans386, on the SCO platform the format used by dbxtra and codeview is supported. On the SVR4.2 platform Dwarf 1 is supported, which is used by debug. On the Solaris, DragonFly, and Linux platforms, stabs is supported. The GNU debugger gdb may be used on all platforms.
For hppatrans, the -H flag causes hppatrans to output xdb compatible debugging information in its output file. This option is only available if the header file hpux_symtab.h was included whilst compiling hppatrans.
hpux_symtab.h is available by anonymous FTP, but appears to have changed location over time. Your best option is to simply google for it.
Please note well that there is a known bug in the -H option for hppatrans. The bug sometimes prohibits xdb reading selective diagnostic information from a suite of two or more modules linked together.
For mipstrans the diagnostic format used is as used by the native compilers.
For sparctrans, the diagnostic format used is stabs for SunOS, and stabs-in-elf for Solaris (both as used by the native compilers).
Debugging information is not output by default for all translators.-P
This option causes trans to output profiling information suitable for use with prof1 or a similar tool (see individual manual pages for details).
On trans386, this option is currently not supported on the Solaris platform.
On alphatrans, this is not fully implemented.
On mipstrans, this option is untested at present, and should not be used.
Profiling information is not output by default for all translators.-Q
This option causes trans to quit before processing its input files. This is particularly useful in conjunction with -V.
For all translators, this is not done by default.-S
For alphatrans, when this option is present alphatrans will produce a symbolic assembler file in addition to its normal outputs. In this case the name of the symbolic assembler file must be present on the command line.
For mipstrans, this option will produce assembly code in the optional .s file.
This option is not present on all other translators.
For all translators where it is supported, this is not done by default.-V
This option causes trans to print its version number and the version of the TDF specification it supports.
For all translators, this is not done by default.-Wswitch
This option determines whether trans should make string literals writable. At present the C producer does not make use of this facility.
For all translators, at present all string literals are writable, and this cannot be altered.-Z
This option causes trans to print the version number of all the TDF capsules it decodes.
For all translators, this is not done by default.Translator-specific options
The following options are specific to trans386:-a
Always use a frame pointer. The default is to avoid using a frame pointer whenever possible. The default results in better performance, but in special cases where the stack is to be processed it may be necessary to enforce the use of a frame pointer.-h
Do not use the .bss segment, always put data into the .data segment even if it is zero. This should very rarely be needed. The default is to use the .bss segment.-kswitch
This option is applicable to DragonFly and Linux platforms only. If this option is on, trans386 will produce output for an ELF binary format assembler, otherwise a.out binary format is assumed. By default this option is on, as appropriate for later versions of Linux.
The following options are specific to hppatrans:-h
The -h flag causes hppatrans to output gdb compatible, i.e. stabs, debugging information in its output file. The -h flag is believed to be valid—any error is a genuine bug.
The -H and -h options will only work if the input TDF capsule contains debugging information.See Also
as1, prof1, tcc1.
